image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

props.synopsis: The court found the man's BMW convertible was "substantially over-insured" for more than $130,000, when he'd purchased it for $25,000 a year before the incident.

title.children: Driver jailed after staging car accident as part of $130,000 insurance fraud attempt

image.altText: A man's hand encloses an orange ball while blood flows from a needle and tube in his forearm.

props.synopsis: Josh Blizzard has a genetic condition called haemochromatosis, where his body absorbs too much iron. The prescribed treatment is to regularly remove blood, and the good news is it's safe for donation.

title.children: Tens of thousands of '100 per cent safe' bags of blood are being binned instead of donated

image.altText: A man walks through journalists and cameras.

props.synopsis: The Federal Court has heard arguments over whether Mr Lehrmann's appeal against the ruling in his failed defamation case should go ahead.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's lawyer says his only way to make money may be 'to go on OnlyFans'

image.altText: political ads on a mobile phone graphic

props.synopsis: The outcome of two misleading assertions in 2022 reinforces what many in Australia have long suspected — that when it comes to the facts, there is one set of rules for politicians and another for everyone else.

title.children: Labor wants 'fundamental' electoral reform but noticeably absent from its plans are the biggest threats to democracy

image.altText: An orage corlfute for Greg Burke of the Belco party and a burgundy corflute for Sneha KC of the Independents for Canberra.

props.synopsis: You've heard a lot from the major parties running in this election – namely Labor, the Liberal and the Greens – but these are the other players in contention.

title.children: Who are the minor parties running in the 2024 ACT election?

image.altText: An older couple smile, standing in a kitchen holding kitchen utensils over a pot full of food.

props.synopsis: The latest Foodbank Hunger Report has found 3.4 million households across Australia are experiencing food insecurity, with low income earners having to skip meals or eat less because they cannot afford enough food.

title.children: Millions of Australians experiencing 'severe' food insecurity and going hungry, report reveals

image.altText: A woman is hugging a golden retriever dog

props.synopsis: Deciding when to end the life of an old or sick pet can be incredibly tough, so many animal owners are now seeking help from bereavement counsellors.

title.children: How do you make the heartbreaking decision to say goodbye to a pet?

image.altText: Andrew Barr wearing a dark grey jacket filling out a form in a polling booth.

props.synopsis: From news, analysis and explainers through to election previews, key electorates and candidates, ACT Votes has the latest on the upcoming state election. Click through to read more.

title.children: ACT Votes 2024 — stay up to date with the latest election news and analysis

image.altText: A teenage boy leaning against a wall holds his head in his hands and sobs with anguish

props.synopsis: Residents and refugees in the city of Jabalia are entering their 11th day under fire as part of a renewed push by the Israel Defense Forces. The IDF says it follows intelligence Hamas is "reforming in the area".

title.children: The controversial plan that retired generals think Israel needs for northern Gaza

image.altText: People in a packed moshpit inside a tent with giant balloons put their hands up as a person on stage jumps up in the air.

props.synopsis: Freedom of Information documents reveal tens of millions of dollars in grants were given to global behemoth Live Nation at a time when Australia's music industry was struggling.

title.children: Music giant Live Nation earned $US23 billion last year. Australian governments have been giving it millions in grants

image.altText: Dozens of people put their hands in the air at a concert.

props.synopsis: A legal firm says it is investigating allegations of "deceptive, misleading or unconscionable conduct". The ticketing company says it is not responsible for setting prices.

title.children: Ticketmaster and Live Nation could face class action from music fans over 'dynamic' ticket pricing

image.altText: A drone that looks like an aeroplane flies through the air.

props.synopsis: Drones have changed the face of modern warfare and are being used from Ukraine to the Middle East, but can Australia keep up with the pace when it comes to its national defence strategy?

title.children: Dragon and Kamikaze drones are harbingers of death in Ukraine. Australia is developing its own strategy

image.altText: A house auction in Norwood

props.synopsis: It's a matter of when, not if, the Reserve Bank will take the knife to interest rates, but first home buyers may only see a fleeting, and possibly minuscule, improvement in affordability.

title.children: More wealth in fewer hands — the great housing rort

image.altText: A silhouetted man stands in front of an inferno, a metal framework visible above it

props.synopsis: The Israeli air force pounded a hospital and food distribution centre in Gaza as well as an apartment building in northern Lebanon, killing and injuring dozens.

title.children: Israeli air strikes kill 32 people across Gaza and northern Lebanon

image.altText: A middle-aged Turkish man with a beard wearing a suit speaks behind a lectern.

props.synopsis: The three laureates were recognised for their work in studying how political institutions are formed, and how they affect prosperity and global inequality.

title.children: Nobel economics prize goes to researchers who showed democratic institutions boost economic growth

props.synopsis: Mental health, technology and artificial intelligence (AI): Here's what hundreds of students, parents and teachers are most concerned about when it comes to education.

title.children: 'The system is broken': Hundreds of ABC readers told us their concerns about education in Australia — this is what they said

image.altText: Classroom chair knocked over

props.synopsis: Arduous paperwork, surveillance and bullying from management are among the challenges teachers say they face amid a nationwide education staff shortage.

title.children: 'I had a nervous breakdown': Abusive, bullying behaviour behind teaching exodus

image.altText: A woman with a tank top and long brown hair smiling, handing out flyers and standing near signage for her election

props.synopsis: With just days until the Pittwater by-election, Liberal candidate Georgia Ryburn is fighting for every last vote. But according to some, independent Jacqui Scruby could see the contest become "a real scrap".

title.children: As NSW Liberals fight to hold Pittwater, a teal candidate claims to hold a trump card

image.altText: An older photo of two smiling men in open-necked shirts, one young, one older and wearing glasses.

props.synopsis: He counts John Howard, the great Liberal survivor, as one of his heroes — but Michael Ferguson must have known there was little he could do to survive what his Tasmanian political opponents had in store for him.

title.children: 'As a former maths teacher, I know the numbers aren't there': Tasmania's deputy premier jumps before he is pushed

image.altText: A person holds a grey Visa card next to a black EFTPOS payment terminal

props.synopsis: There is an end in sight for consumers getting hit with sneaky surcharges when they pay on card, with the federal government prepared to ban the practice by 2026, promising to give consumers and small businesses "a fair go."

title.children: Debit card surcharges to be scrapped by 2026, government promises

image.altText: The black metal gate of a housing estate with the words "Lifestyle Wollert" on a wall.

props.synopsis: As shares in Lifestyle Communities continue to drop, company managing director James Kelly announces he will retire.

title.children: Lifestyle Communities boss to retire months after allegation that properties are a 'financial prison'

image.altText: Elise Hodder poses during a photo shoot, looking across the camera and seen from side profile.

props.synopsis: The parents of a 24-year-old woman killed when she was struck by a car during a party in a park in Melbourne's eastern suburbs on Sunday morning say she was a "beautiful soul with a radiance that touched everybody".

title.children: Elise Hodder, 24, identified as victim of fatal crash during park party

image.altText: Donald Trump speaks during a rally.

props.synopsis: Police in California say they may have thwarted a third assassination attempt on Donald Trump after arresting a man with a loaded gun outside one of the former president's rallies.

title.children: 'It prevented the third assassination attempt': The back story of the man accused of trying to bring a loaded gun to a Trump rally

image.altText: A close up of the Premier wearing a white hard hat

props.synopsis: WA's Town of Port Hedland council has passed a motion urging state and federal governments to suspend COVID-19 vaccines, prompting the Premier to say they should "stick to their knitting" and stop spreading unverified claims.

title.children: 'Off the rails' council backs COVID conspiracy and calls for vaccines to be scrapped

image.altText: People in Hazmat suits walk out of a door way, red paint can be seen on the wall.

props.synopsis: Peter Khalil's electorate office has been doused with an unknown substance, in what the government's special envoy for social cohesion has called an "escalation" of previous incidents.

title.children: 'It smells like an abattoir': Labor MP's electorate office sprayed with red paint and unknown substances

image.altText: US Air Force members stand underneath and aircraft by a Army Terminal High Altitude Area Defense air defence system.

props.synopsis: The Pentagon is bolstering Israel's air defences with a THAAD system to specifically target Iran's ballistic missile attacks, and 100 US troops to operate it.

title.children: US plans to send Israel an extra air defence system and 100 troops to operate it. This is what it means

image.altText: A picture of Andrew Truman in a suit on a staircase.

props.synopsis: Family and friends of Andrew Truman have paid tribute to the 44-year-old who died after an alleged assault in Melbourne's CBD last week. Police are still searching for a man over the incident.

title.children: Family in shock over CBD assault death of 'vibrant' Melbourne man

image.altText: Peter Dutton smiles while sitting in the house of representatives

props.synopsis: It's not that long ago that reports of Peter Dutton's premature death as opposition leader were being greatly exaggerated. Now he's suddenly found himself leading Labor for the first time.

title.children: Peter Dutton has plenty to smile about as major poll gives him the lead

image.altText: Woman with blonde and black sweater stands on busy street at night, the background action blurred

props.synopsis: Someone spent years plastering deepfake porn of Hannah Grundy online. It was a betrayal that turned her life upside down.

title.children: Hannah found deepfake porn of herself online. But the most disturbing revelation was still to come

image.altText: Michael Ferguson resignation press conference, 14 October 2024

props.synopsis: One of the most senior members of the Tasmanian Liberal government, Michael Ferguson, has resigned from cabinet in the face of growing scrutiny over the bungled rollout of new Spirit of Tasmania vessels.

title.children: Tasmania's deputy premier resigns from cabinet ahead of no-confidence motion

image.altText: Woman watching over ICU crib, looking at her baby sleeping.

props.synopsis: Families face an expensive legal battle to prove medical negligence in Australia, but experts say reforms that New Zealand undertook two decades ago offer a solution.

title.children: Australian patients have a hard time proving medical negligence, but in NZ it's a different story

image.altText: A probe orbiting a cream and red moon, with Jupiter seen in the distance.

props.synopsis: An imposing NASA probe scheduled to lift off as Australia sleeps might take the first real step toward finding out if anywhere else in our solar system could support life.

title.children: NASA says this Jupiter moon 'might be habitable today, right now' — so they're going to take a look

image.altText: A grey jet in the sky.

props.synopsis: China's military commences a new round of war games near Taiwan, aimed at signalling a stern warning to the island's pro-independence movements.

title.children: China launches military drills around Taiwan as a warning against independence

image.altText: Back of grey-haired woman's head at desk with computer screen and take-away coffee cup

props.synopsis: Police are investigating after a 60-year-old Cairns woman lost more than $200,000 in an online scam. The scammer claimed he worked in the military overseas and eventually asked her for money.

title.children: 60yo woman loses $200k after making 'many' payments to man in online romance scam

image.altText: Members of the Rebels motorcycle club

props.synopsis: Digital technology is changing how the underworld operates. According to a senior policeman, it's leading to younger crews with less experience stepping up and performing serious crimes and putting the public at risk.

title.children: The way killing is undertaken in Australia's underworld is changing
